SWEARING.

From the form of the prohibition, we might suppose that St. James took the same view 01 the siibject as St. Augustine, quoted in the note, and forbade swearing, not so much because it was wrong in itself, as because it was likely to lead to wrong, and therefore to con- demnation. Whatever their practice was, they would certainly allow that there was much careless and irreverent swearing, and that this could not but be displeasiug to God. St. James is, however, quoting Christ’s own words, and it is therefore probable that he means ‘Whatever form 01 oath you use, it will come under the prohibition 01 Christi! Are we to understand from this that every kind 01 swearing is absolutely for- bidden, that the Quakers, for instance, were right in refusing to take an oath in a court 01 justice? This is not what we should gather from the conduct of St. Paul and 01 Christ Himself. The former calls God to witness that he is speaking the truth in more than one passage <2 Cor. i. 23, xi. 31, Gal. i. 20, etc), and our Lord took the oath proposed to Him in the words of the High Priest ‘ I adjure thee by the living clod) So the angel in the Apocalypse is represented as swearing ‘ by Him that hveth 101· ever and ever.' The same rule of interpretation must be applied here as in the case 01 the other precepts 01 the Sermon on the Mount. They supply an ideal standard, a goal to be aimed at, but not a code 01 law to be immediately put into execution, regardless 01 existing circumstances, and 01 the manner in which their exact observance would affect our carrying out the two great commandments on which hang all the law and the prophets. Take for instance the precept to turn the other cheek : if this is tried by the principle that we should do to others as we would wish them to do to us, it is evident that the last thing which a sane man could wish for himself or for one whom he loved would be that he should be allowed to strike and insult others with impunity. We have to disregard the letter, in order to keep the spirit 01 the precept 5 which is that a Christian should never act from mere vindictiveness. The law 01 love requires us to act for the best interest 01 the offender, i.e. to act in such a way as to induce him to avoid such faults in future. It is only where there is sufficient generosity 01 character to make a man ashamed of striking one who offers no resistance, that non-resistance becomes the fitting course for a Christian, the right way 01 obey ing the law ‘ Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyselfi' Yet in proportion as a society becomes Chris- tianized, it becomes more and more possible to practise non-resistance without transgressing the higher law 01 love, which bids us always act for the best interest of our neighbour.
